snippet: Some Alawites have been frustrated that security forces have not crushed the opposition, while others say President Bashar al-Assad is pushing the sect to the brink of civil war with Sunni Muslims.
abstract: Pres Bashar al-Assad of Syria has increasingly relied on his fellow Alawite Muslims for support as sectarian strife escalates in the country, but interviews reveal a growing rift within that religious community; some Alawites are frustrated that security forces have not yet managed to crush the opposition, while others feel Assad is risking the future of the Alawites by pushing them to the brink of civil war with Sunni Muslims.

byline.contributor: Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.

lead_paragraph: Some Alawites have been frustrated that security forces have not crushed the opposition, while others say President Bashar al-Assad is pushing the sect to the brink of civil war with Sunni Muslims.
